clinical_study.brief_title: Measurement of Anterior Chamber Cell Grading Using Ocular Coherence Tomography
clinical_study.official_title: Objective, Prospective Measurement of Anterior Chamber Cell Grading Using Anterior Chamber Ocular Coherence Tomography

lead_sponsor.agency: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

clinical_study.source: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

brief_summary.textblock: Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is routinely used in ophthalmic clinical practice. It uses infrared light to image patient's eyes. Some patients, such as those with an inflammatory disease called uveitis or those who have just undergone cataract surgery, have intraocular inflammation. This intraocular inflammation commonly manifests as cells that can be seen on routine microscopic clinical examination. However, the only currently available method to quantify this intraocular inflammation is by manually counting on the microscopic clinical examination. The investigators plan to use the OCT machine to image patient's eyes. The investigators will then use the images obtained from the OCT to objectively quantify the degree of intraocular inflammation.

primary_outcome.measure: Identification of inflammatory cells on OCT scan
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, up to 1 year.
primary_outcome.description: Identification of cells in OCT scan

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in cell density identified by OCT scans over time
secondary_outcome.description: Identification of changes in cell density in OCT scans over time

arm_group.description: Subjects will undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans.
Control subjects will undergo a brief, non-contact eye exam and then undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans.

intervention.description: The OCT scan is a brief, non-contact scan of the back of the eye using infrared light. Subjects will see a light and be asked to look forwards while the scan is completed.
This is a brief, non-contact ocular exam.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age over 18 years old
- Intervention Arm:
- Active anterior chamber inflammation in at least one eye as diagnosed by clinical exam
- One of the following: 1) diagnosis of uveitis OR 2) undergone cataract extraction surgery within the previous 30 days
- Control Arm:
- No active intraocular inflammation based on clinical exam
Exclusion Criteria:
- Corneal opacities in the affected eye
- Anyone judged unable to understand or consent to study participation
